sample.content:
"Here comes a perfectly valid argument: To begin with, no loyal buyer of Tom's of Maine soap is a frequent consumer of Neutrogena soap and, in the same time, an owner of a Shield soap. Moreover, whoever is both a frequent consumer of Neutrogena soap and an owner of a Shield soap is a loyal buyer of Tom's of Maine soap or an occasional purchaser of Clairol shampoo.we may conclude that everyone who is both a frequent consumer of Neutrogena soap and an owner of a Shield soap is an occasional purchaser of Clairol shampoo, too."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
sample.name: example_user

sample.content:
"It is not always easy to see who is related to whom -- and in which ways. The following argument pertains to this question: To begin with, Darrell is not a brother of Ward. Moreover, being a brother of Ward is sufficient for being a cousin of Edward. In consequence, it is false that Darrell is a cousin of Edward."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
sample.name: example_user

sample.content:
"Consumer research aims at understanding whether users of some products also tend to consume other ones, or not. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: First, being a frequent consumer of Shiseido shampoo is necessary for not being a rare consumer of Colgate-Palmolive soap. Second, everyone who is not a frequent consumer of Fels-Naptha soap is however a frequent consumer of Shiseido shampoo and a regular consumer of Aveeno soap. Third, nobody is neither a rare consumer of Colgate-Palmolive soap nor a regular consumer of Aveeno soap. We may conclude: Being a frequent consumer of Fels-Naptha soap is necessary for not being a rare consumer of Colgate-Palmolive soap."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
sample.name: example_user

sample.content:
"Is Titanium oxide an ingredient of my washing power? Which chemicals does my perfume contain? It is really difficult to keep track of all chemicals one is regularly exposed to. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: First premise: To be an ingredient of Puddy Holly or an ingredient of Merry Macaron Set is necessary for being an ingredient of Neon Purple. Second premise: Every ingredient of Hey, Twirl-friend! is not an ingredient of Merry Macaron Set or not an ingredient of Puddy Holly. We may conclude that no ingredient of Neon Purple is an ingredient of Hey, Twirl-friend!."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
sample.name: example_user
